Award.AwardTitle: LTREB Renewal: Population and community ecology of desert winter annuals
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project extends a 30-year study of desert plant populations to understand how populations persist and coexist in the face of short-term environmental variation and long-term climate shifts. Data on seed germination, plant survival, and reproduction will continue to be collected to determine how seeds are triggered to germinate and when - or why - germination is delayed to take advantage of different environmental conditions. These decisions are largely responsible for changes in plant abundance and species coexistence in this community. Field measures will be combined with experiments to develop models to explore how seed 'banks,' or accumulations of ungerminated seeds, buffer populations and communities against short- and long-term environmental variation. These models will also be used to investigate how differences among species promote their coexistence and species diversity and to predict how desert plant communities will respond to emerging novel climatic conditions.

Like human communities, natural communities are challenged by increasing environmental variation and shifting climate. This research will determine how plant communities cope with normal environmental variability and how they will respond to a hotter, drier, more variable environment. Graduate and undergraduate students will receive hands-on training in research that complements formal coursework. Several activities will extend the impact of the research to the public, K-12 students and teachers, and ecosystem management professionals. These include an educational kiosk at the University of Arizona's Biosphere 2 facility, coordination with the Arizona Center for STEM Teachers, and participation in a new Center for Environmental Biology that brings together land managers and university scientists from the southwestern U.S.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has contributed to our understanding of how plants adapt to and coexist in variable and unpredictable environments. We collected population and community dynamic data on germination, survival, and reproduction of desert annuals every year of the grant period (and the 25 preceding years). These results demonstrated the highly variable dynamics of desert annuals and documented long-term trends attributable to warming and drying of the climate beyond the envelope of variation found in the 20th century.  Despite this variability and shifting species composition in response to novel directional environmental change, species diversity has been resilient.

While documenting these long-term trends in population and community dynamics in response to climate change is itself and important advance in knowledge, we additionally wanted to gain a mechanistic understanding of why some species increased while others decreased, and mechanisms underlying maintenance of species diversity in the face of fluctuating and directional environmental change. We discovered that species varied in their efficiency in the use of water (WUE) and in their inherent speed of plant growth (RGR) such that species with high WUE have low RGR and vice versa.  A species position on this gradient of growth strategies has a cascade of consequences.  High RGR-low WUE species have higher interannual population variability, greater reliance on inter-year seed bank delays, later and longer life history transitions, smaller seed size, lower seedling survival, higher fecundity, and a multidecadal pattern of population decline, while low RGR-high WUE species show the opposite trends.  Some paradoxical results were found.  For example, as climate has warmed and dried, germination time has shifted later towards the December and winter annual plants have experienced cooler conditions following germination. Also paradoxical, water-use-efficient plants are better able to grow at low temperatures than fast-growing water-use-inefficient plants.  Thus, WUE plants have increased relative to RGR plants during a period of climate warming and drying by virtue of their ability to accumulate carbon when it is cold. 

Desert annuals are one of the most tractable systems used to exemplify non-equilibrium community dynamics. This is because annual plants have short life cycles and small body size facilitating the study of many generations and many individuals (compared to perennial plants). We demonstrated how species differences in growth responses and germination provide a mechanism to maintain species diversity. Also, desert annuals live in high-variance environments in which water availability is generally agreed to be a major driving variable. This has made them a model system for the development of general concepts about adaptation to environmental variability. This project provided the critical long-term data on demographic variation that is needed to ?unpack? this theory in the context of the model system that motivated much of the original theoretical development. We have used our data to parameterize models of bet-hedging and shown that populations are indeed behaving as expected if they had evolved to hedge their bets in the face of environmental uncertainty. This study has provided the best evidence to date for evolutionary bet-hedging.

This grant has contributed substantially to human resource development at the undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral levels. More than 40 undergraduates learned to do research responsibly and work and teach one another as members of a team. Many of them subsequently attended graduate school or become biology teachers. Research Specialists learn how to teach and manage people in a scientific research setting. This project had an impact on graduate education with graduate students conducting research on the project and parallel to the project. Postdocs also received useful training and achieved research productivity including a postdoc recently tenured in EEB at UC Davis and another in Botany and Zoology at the University of British Columbia. 

Our research results are widely known and used in introductory and advanced classes in Ecology at universities around the world. The project is responsible for the production and maintenance of several long-term ecological data bases. These archiving efforts not only bring Desert Laboratory legacy data sets to the broader community, but they also permit future researchers to continue long-term research on these systems. We have been involved in many outreach activities including production of a mobile app for the thousands of visitors at the Desert Laboratory where our work is conducted, a Massive Open Online Course (MOOC), and engagement with many university outreach venues.
